TerrainGen Documentation > Expo
(revised 5/13/11)

Index | Generation | Blocks | Expo
This code is free software; you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the GNU General Public License
as published by the Free Software Foundation. This code is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but
WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of MERCHANTABILITY or
FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. See the GNU General Public License for more details.

85 color constants are built into the DELUXE Expo class
The 10 main colors are red, green, blue, orange, cyan, magenta, yellow, gray, pink and tan.
Each of these colors has 4 other shades which simply require the prefix "light", "dark", "lighter" or "darker".
For example, the 5 shades of red are: red, lightRed, darkRed, lighterRed and darkerRed.

The following colors are also included without multiple shades:
black, white, brown, violet, purple, turquoise, plum, indigo, aqua, aquaMarine, goldenRod, gold, silver, bronze,
teal, maroon, fuschia, lavender, lime, navy, chartreuse, fireBrick, moccasin, olive, salmon, khaki, crimson,
orchid, sienna, melon, tangerine, terraCotta, pumpkin, mahogany, and amber.

NOTE:  Some colors are duplicates.  "navy" is the same as "darkBlue";  "silver" is the same as "lightGray"; and "aqua" is the same as "cyan".         

The following real numbers constants are also built in:
twoPI, which equals 2 * Math.PI
halfPI, which equals Math.PI / 2;
quarterPI, which equals Math.PI / 4;

Method Summary
center(String str)
          Displays centered text on an 80 column text screen.
          Example:
          Expo.center("Hello World");
          This will display "Hello World" centered horizontally on the text screen..
cube(double number)
          Returns the "cube" of number, which is number raised to the 3rd power.
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.cube(2));
          This will display 8.0
cubeRoot(double number)
          Returns the cubeRoot (3rd root) of number.
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.cubeRoot(8));
          This will display 2.0
delay(int n)
          Delays the output for a specified number of milliseconds (1/1000ths of a second).
          Examples:
          Expo.delay(1000); // delay for 1 second
          Expo.delay(2000); // delay for 2 seconds
          Expo.delay(500);  // delay for 1/2 of a second
          Expo.delay(100);  // delay for 1/10 of a second
          Expo.delay(10);   // delay for 1/100 of a second
          Expo.delay(1);    // delay for 1/1000 of a second
displayGUI(String temp)
          Displays a String in a GUI window.
          The window will stay on the screen until the user clicks "OK".
          Example:
          Expo.displayGUI("Hello World");
          Displays "Hello World" in a GUI window
          NOTE: This method also works with int, double, char and boolean values.
          Example:
          Expo.displayGUI(25);
          Displays "25" in a GUI window
drawArc(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius, int start, int finish)
          Draws and arc which looks like a curve.  An ARC is a "piece" of an OVAL.
          The first 5 parameters (g and 4 ints) are the same as drawOval.
          There are 2 additional parameters for the starting degree value and finishing degree of the arc.
          0 degrees is at the 12:00 position and the degrees progress in a CLOCKWISE fashion.
          (90 degrees is at 3:00, 180 degrees is at 6:00, 270 degrees is at 9:00, 360 degrees is back at 12:00).
drawBurst(java.awt.Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int numLines)
          Draws a certain number of lines (numLines) in a burst like pattern.
          The lines are evenly spaced and drawn from the center of a circle to its edge.
          The size of the circle is specified by the radius parameter.
          Example:
          Expo.drawBurst(g,300,200,100,50);
          Draws a "burst" with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
          The "burst" will be comprised of 50 evenly spaced lines.
drawCircle(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius)
          Draws an open circle.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the circle as well as the radius value.
          Example:
          Expo.drawCircle(g,300,200,100);
          Draws an open circle with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
drawLine(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2)
          Draws the line segment connecting coordinates x1,y1 and x2,y2.
          Example:
          Expo.drawLine(g,100,200,300,400);
          Draws a line segment connecting the starting coordinate point (100,200) with the ending point (300,400).
drawOval(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius)
          Draws an open oval.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the oval as well as the horizontal and vertical radii values.
          Example:
          Expo.drawOval(g,300,200,100,50);
          Draws an open oval with a horizontal radius of 100 pixels and a vertical radius of 50 pixels.
          The center of this oval is located at the coordinate (300,200).
drawPixel(Graphics g, int x, int y)
          Draws a single pixel at the specified x,y location.
          Example:
          Expo.drawPixel(g,100,200);
          Draws a very small single dot (pixel) on the computer screen 100 pixels over and 200 pixels down.
drawPoint(Graphics g, int x, int y)
          Draws a 3 pixel X 3 pixel "point" whose center is at the specified x,y location.
          Example:
          Expo.drawPoint(g,100,200);
          Draws a larger, more visible (than drawPixel) dot on the computer screen 100 pixels over and 200 pixels down.
drawPolygon(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, ... ,int x12, int y12)
          Draws an open irregular polygon using between 3 and 12 sets of provided coordinates.
          Examples:
          Expo.drawPolygon(g,100,300,200,100,300,300);                           // for a triangle
          Expo.drawPolygon(g,525,300,600,250,650,250,725,300,725,350,650,400);   // for a hexagon
drawPreciseSpiral(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int maxRadius, double spacing)
          Draws a spiral whose spacing is precisely controlled by the "spacing" parameter.
          The center of the spiral is specified with the centerX,centerY parameters.
          The maxRadius parameter determines the size of the spiral
          (It is actually the radius of the circle that the spiral would fit inside.)
          Example:
          Expo.drawPreciseSpiral(g,300,200,100,25);
          Draws a spiral with a maxRadius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
          There are precisely 25 pixels separating each "loop" of the spiral.
drawQuad(java.awt.Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, int x4, int y4)
          Draws an open irregular quadrilateral using the four sets of provided coordinates.
          Example:
          Expo.drawQuad(g,100,100,200,300,400,400,300,200);
drawRandomBurst(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int numLines)
          Draws a certain number of random lines in a burst like pattern.
          The lines have random colors, random lengths and are drawn in random directions.
          The parameters are the same as drawBurst.
          Postcondition: The current drawing color will not be affected by the randomly colored lines.
          Example:
          Expo.drawRandomBurst(g,300,200,100,50);
          Draws a "random burst" with a max radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
          The "burst" will be comprised of 50 lines with random spacing, random length and random color.
drawRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2)
         Draws an open rectangle.
         The upper-left-hand corner is specified by x1,y1 and the lower-right-hand corner is specified by x2, y2.
         Example:
         Expo.drawRectangle(g,100,200,300,400);
         Draws an open rectangle whose upper-left-hand coordinate is (100,200) and whose lower-right-hand coordinate is (300,400).
drawRegularPolygon(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int sides)
          Draws an open regular polygon with a specified number of sides.
          The center of this polygon is specified by centerX,centerY and its size is specified by radius
          (As in the radius of the circle the regular polygon would fit inside).
          Precondition: sides >= 3
          Example:
          Expo.drawRegularPolygon(g,300,200,100,8);
          Draws an open regular octagon with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
drawRoundedRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int pixels )
          Draws an open rectangle with rounded corners.
          The first 5 parameters (g and 4 ints) are the same as drawRect.
          The final parameter "pixels" specifies the number of pixels used in the rounded corner.
          Example:
          Expo.drawRoundedRectangle(g,100,200,300,400,25);
drawSpiral(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int maxRadius)
          Draws a spiral.
          The center of the spiral is specified with the centerX,centerY parameters.
          The maxRadius parameter determines the size of the spiral
          (It is actually the radius of the circle that the spiral would fit inside).
          Example:
          Expo.drawSpiral(g,300,200,100);
          Draws a spiral with a maxRadius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
drawStar(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int points)
          Draws an open star with a specified number of points.
          The center of this star is specified by centerX,centerY and its size is specified by radius
          (As in the radius of the circle the star would fit inside).
          Precondition: points >= 2
          Example:
          Expo.drawStar(g,300,200,100,8);
          Draws an open star with 8 points and a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
drawString(Graphics g, java.lang.String s, int x, int y)
          Draws a String s on the graphics screen at a certain x,y coordinate.
          The coordinate x,y is the location of the bottom-left corner of the first character in the String s.
          Example:
          Expo.drawString(g,"Hello There!",100,200);
drawThickArc(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius, int start, int finish, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" arc which will look like a thick curved line.
          The parameters are the same as drawArc, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickBurst(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int numLines, int thickness)
          Draws a certain number of "thick" lines in a burst like pattern.
          The parameters are the same as drawBurst, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickCircle(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" circle.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the circle as well as the radius value.
          The thickness is specified in the last parameter.
          Example:
          Expo.drawThickCircle(g,300,200,100,5);
          Draws a "thick" open circle with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
          The edge of this circle will be 5 pixels thick.
drawThickLine(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" line segment connecting coordinates x1,y2 and x2,y2.
          The thickness is specified in the last parameter.
          Example:
          Expo.drawThickLine(g,100,200,300,400,5);
          Draws a "thick" line segment connecting the starting coordinate point (100,200) with the ending point (300,400).
          The line will be 5 pixels thick.
drawThickOval(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" oval.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the oval as well as the horizontal and vertical radii values.
          The thickness is specified in the last parameter.
          Example:
          Expo.drawThickOval(g,300,200,100,50,5);
          Draws a "thick" open oval with a horizontal radius of 100 pixels and a vertical radius of 50 pixels.
          The center of this oval is located at the coordinate (300,200).
          The edge of this oval will be 5 pixels thick.
drawThickPreciseSpiral(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int maxRadius, double spacing, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" and "precise" spiral.
          The parameters are the same as drawPreciseSpiral, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickQuad(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, int x4, int y4, int thickness)
          Draws an "thick" open irregular quadrilateral using the four sets of provided coordinates.
          The parameters are the same as drawQuad, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickRandomBurst(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int numLines, int thickness)
          Draws a certain number of random "thick" lines in a burst like pattern.
          The "thick" lines have random colors, random lengths and are drawn in random directions.
          The parameters are the same as drawRandomBurst, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
          Postcondition: The current drawing color will not be affected by the randomly colored thick lines.
drawThickRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" open rectangle.
          The parameters are the same as drawRectangle, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickRegularPolygon(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int sides, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" regular polygon with a specified number of sides.
          The parameters are the same as drawRegularPolygon, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
          Precondition: sides >= 3
drawThickRoundedRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int pixels, int thickness)
          Draws an "thick" open rectangle with rounded corners.
          The first 5 parameters (g and 4 ints) are the same as drawRect.
          The 6th parameter "pixels" specifies the number of pixels used in the rounded corner.
          The final parameter soecifies the thickness.
          Example:
          Expo.drawThickRoundedRectangle(g,100,200,300,400,25,10);
drawThickSpiral(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int maxRadius, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" spiral.
          The parameters are the same as drawSpiral, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawThickStar(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int points, int thickness)
          Draws a "thick" star with a specified number of points.
          The parameters are the same as drawBurst, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
          Precondition: points >= 2
drawThickTriangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, int thickness)
          Draws an "thick" open irregular triangle using the three sets of provided coordinates.
          The parameters are the same as drawTriangle, except there is an extra parameter at the end for the thickness.
drawTriangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3)
          Draws an open irregular triangle using the three sets of provided coordinates.
          Example:
          Expo.drawTriangle(g,100,300,200,100,300,300);
enterBoolean()
          Allows input of a boolean (true or false) from the keyboard in a text window.
          The user can enter the word "true" or "false".
          The method is not case sensitive. (True, trUE, TruE will all work)
          The user can also enter T or F.
          The user can also enter 1 for true and 0 for false.
          The user can also enter A for true and B for false.
          The user can also enter Y for true/yes and N for false/no.
          Essentially, anything that does not begin with a 'T', '1', 'A' or 'Y' will be interpreted as "false".
          System.out.print("Registered voter. (Enter T or F) --> ");
          boolean voter = Expo.enterBoolean();
enterBooleanGUI(java.lang.String prompt)
          Allows input of a boolean (true or false) from the keyboard using a GUI window.
          The String parameter "prompt" is a message that tells the user what he/she is suppose to enter.
          Example:
          boolean voter = Expo.enterBooleanGUI("Registered voter. (Enter T or F)");
enterChar()
          Allows input of a char from the keyboard in a text window.
          Example:
          System.out.print("What is your middle initial? --> ");
          char middleInitial = Expo.enterChar();
enterCharGUI(java.lang.String prompt)
          Allows input of a char from the keyboard using a GUI window.
          The String parameter "prompt" is a message that tells the user what he/she is suppose to enter.
          Example:
          char middleInitial = Expo.enterCharGUI("What is youe middle initial?");
enterDouble()
          Allows input of a double (real number) from the keyboard in a text window.
          Example:
          System.out.print("What is your current GPA? {0.00 - 4.00} --> ");
          double gpa = Expo.enterDouble();
enterDoubleGUI(java.lang.String prompt)
          Allows input of a double (real number) from the keyboard using a GUI window.
          The String parameter "prompt" is a message that tells the user what he/she is suppose to enter.
          Example:
          double gpa = Expo.enterDoubleGUI("What is your GPA? {0.00 - 4.00}");
enterInt()
          Allows input of an int (integer) from the keyboard in a text window.
          Example:
          System.out.print("How old are you? --> ");
          int age = Expo.enterInt();
enterIntGUI(java.lang.String prompt)
          Allows GUI input of an int (integer) from the keyboard.
          Example:
          int age = Expo.enterIntGUI("How old are you?");
enterString()
          Allows input of a String from the keyboard in a text window.
          Example:
          System.out.print("What is your name? ---> ");
          String name = Expo.enterString();
enterStringGUI(java.lang.String prompt)
          Allows input of a String from the keyboard using a GUI window.
          The String parameter "prompt" is a message that tells the user what he/she is suppose to enter.
          Example:
          String name = Expo.enterStringGUI("What is your name?");
fillArc(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius, int start, int finish)
          Draws a "solid" arc which will look either like a pie wedge or Pac-man.
          A FILLED ARC is a "piece" of a SOLID OVAL.
          The first 5 parameters (g and 4 ints) are the same as fillOval.
          There are 2 additional parameters for the starting degree value and finishing degree of the arc.
          0 degrees is at the 12:00 position and the degrees progress in a CLOCKWISE fashion.
          (90 degrees is at 3:00, 180 degrees is at 6:00, 270 degrees is at 9:00, 360 degrees is back at 12:00).
fillCircle(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius)
          Draws a solid "filled in" circle.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the circle as well as the radius value.
          Example:
          Expo.fillCircle(g,300,200,100);
          Draws a solid circle with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
fillOval(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int hRadius, int vRadius)
          Draws a solid "filled in" oval.
          The user specifies the x,y coordinate of the center of the oval as well as the horizontal and vertical radii values.
          Example:
          Expo.fillOval(g,300,200,100,50);
          Draws a solid oval with a horizontal radius of 100 pixels and a vertical radius of 50 pixels.
          The center of this oval is located at the coordinate (300,200).
fillPolygon(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, ... ,int x12, int y12)
          Draws a solid "filled-in" irregular polygon using between 3 and 12 sets of provided coordinates.
          Examples:
          Expo.fillPolygon(g,100,300,200,100,300,300);                           // for a triangle
          Expo.fillPolygon(g,525,300,600,250,650,250,725,300,725,350,650,400);   // for a hexagon
fillQuad(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3, int x4, int y4)
          Draws an solid "filled-in" irregular quadrilateral using the four sets of provided coordinates.
          Example:
          Expo.fillQuad(g,100,100,200,300,400,400,300,200);
fillRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2)
          Draws a solid "filled in" rectangle.
          The upper-left-hand corner is specified by x1,y1 and the lower-right-hand corner is specified by x2, y2.
          Example:
          Expo.fillRectangle(g,100,200,300,400);
          Draws an open rectangle whose upper-left-hand coordinate is (100,200) and whose lower-right-hand coordinate is (300,400).
fillRegularPolygon(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int sides)
          Draws a solid "filled in" regular polygon with a specified number of sides.
          The center of this polygon is specified by centerX,centerY and its size is specified by radius
          (As in the radius of the circle the regular polygon would fit inside).
          Precondition: sides >= 3
          Example:
          Expo.fillRegularPolygon(g,300,200,100,8);
          Draws a solid "filled-in" regular octagon with a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
fillRoundedRectangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int pixels)
          Draws a solid "filled in" rectangle with rounded corners.
          The first 5 parameters (g and 4 ints) are the same as drawRect.
          The final parameter "pixels" specifies the number of pixels used in the rounded corner.
          Example:
          Expo.fillRoundedRectangle(g,100,200,300,400,25,10);
fillStar(Graphics g, int centerX, int centerY, int radius, int points)
          Draws a solid "filled in" star with a specified number of points.
          The center of this star is specified by centerX,centerY and its size is specified by radius
          (As in the radius of the circle the star would fit inside).
          Precondition: points >= 2
          Example:
          Expo.fillStar(g,300,200,100,8);
          Draws a solid star with 8 points and a radius of 100 pixels whose center is located at the coordinate (300,200).
fillTriangle(Graphics g, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2, int x3, int y3)
          Draws an solid "filled-in" irregular triangle using the three sets of provided coordinates.
          Example:
          Expo.fillTriangle(g,100,300,200,100,300,300);
getRandomColor()
          Returns a random Color object which can be any of the 16,000,000+ possible colors.
          Example:
          Color rndColor = getRandomColor();
logBase10(double number)
          Returns the log base 10 of number.
          This solves the equation: 10? = number
          Precondition: number > 0
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.logBase10(1000));
          This will display 3.0 because 103 = 1000.
logBase2(double number)
          Returns the log base 2 of number.
          This solves the equation: 2? = number
          Precondition: number > 0
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.logBase2(128));
          This will display 7.0 because 27 = 128.
logBaseX(double number, double base)
          Returns the log of a number with a base specified by the user.
          This solves the equation: base? = number
          Preconditions: number > 0, base > 0
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.logBaseX(81,3));
          This will display 4.0 because 34 = 81.
pause()
          Pauses the output and waits for the user to press the [enter] key.
          Example:
          Expo.pause();
random(int min, int max)
          Returns a "true" random integer in the [min..max] range, inclusive.
          Precondition: max > min
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.random(100,200));
          This will display a random integer between 100 and 200.
rightJustify(java.lang.String str)
          Displays right-justified text on an 80 column text screen.
          Example:
          Expo.rightJustify("Hello World");
          This will display "Hello World" on the far right side of the text screen.
root(double number, double x)
          Returns the xth root of number.
          Preconditions: number > 0, root != 0
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.root(1000000,6));
          This will display the 6th root of 1000000, which is 10.0         
setBackground(Graphics g, java.awt.Color bgColor)
          Sets the entire background to a single color using a Color object parameter.
          Precondition: The applet window cannot be greater than 4800 X 3600 in size.
          Example:
          Expo.setBackground(g,Expo.red);
          This will make the entire background red.
          36 colors constants are built into the Expo class.  These colors are listed near the top of this file.
setBackground(Graphics g, int colorNum)
          Sets the entire background to one of 10 predefined primary colors using a single int parameter.
          0 = black         1 = red         2 = green         3 = blue         4 = orange         5 = cyan          6 = magenta        7 = yellow        8 = gray        9 = pink
          Any negative number will give you white.
          Example:
          Expo.setBackground(g,1);
          Changes the background color to red.
setBackground(Graphics g, int red, int green, int blue)
          Sets the entire background to a single color using 3 int parameters representing the amount of red, green and blue.
          This allows for more than 16 million different color combinations.
          Preconditions: All 3 color values need to be between 0 and 255 inclusive.
          The applet window cannot be greater than 4800 X 3600 in size.
          Example:
          Expo.setBackground(g,190,10,47);
          Changes the background color to the shade of red used in the official Texas Flag.
setColor(Graphics g, java.awt.Color newColor)
          Allows the user to change the color, using a Color object parameter.
          Example:
          Expo.setColor(g,Expo.red);
          Changes the current drawing color to red.
          85 color constants are built into the Expo class.  These colors are listed near the top of this file.
setColor(Graphics g, int colorNum)
          Allows the user to change to one of 10 predefined primary colors using a single int parameter.
          This is especially useful in programs where you want to change from one color to a contrasting color quickly.
          0 = black         1 = red         2 = green         3 = blue         4 = orange         5 = cyan          6 = magenta        7 = yellow        8 = gray        9 = pink
          Any negative number will give you white.
          Example:
          Expo.setColor(g,1);
          Changes the current drawing color to red.
setColor(Graphics g, int red, int green, int blue)
          Allows the user to change the color, using 3 int parameters representing the amount of red, green and blue.
          This allows for more than 16 million different color combinations.
          Precondition: All 3 color values need to be between 0 and 255 inclusive.
          Example:
          Expo.setColor(g,190,10,47);
          Changes the current drawing color to the shade of red used in the official Texas Flag
setFont(Graphics g, String name, int style, int size)
          Allows you to change the current "font" used by the drawString method.
          Example:
          Expo.setFont(g,"Arial",Font.BOLD,36);
          Changes the font to Arial Bold with a Point Size of 36
          NOTE:   If drawString is used without this command, you will get the default font of Arial Plain with a Point Size of 12
                        Using a Font name that is misspelled or does not exist will result in getting the default Font of Arial.
                        There are 4 Font styles available: Font.PLAIN, Font.BOLD, Font.ITALIC and Font.BOLD+Font.ITALIC
setRandomColor(Graphics g)
          Sets the current color to a random color value which can be any of the 16,000,000+ possible colors.
          Example:
          Expo.setRandomColor(g);
skip(int n)
          Utility method that will skip a certain number of blank lines on a text output screen.
           This is used to space out text output.
           Example:
           Expo.skip(4);
           This will display 4 blank lines.
square(double number)
          Returns the "square" number, which is the number multiplied times itself.
          Example:
          System.out.println(Expo.square(5));
          This will display 25.0
